Name: Worked flint flake
Description: Small pointed flint tool, cut for use as a scraper, one of two from the tomb at Abydos of a court servant of the 1st Dynasty, period of the earliest recorded unification of Egypt, around 3000 BC. The small grave also contained four ivory arrow heads, two pieces of thin copper band, a cowrie and two other shells, a spherical blue-glazed bead, a bead covered with gold foil, and the fragment of an alabaster bowl. These grave goods confirm the status of the tomb-owner, not amongst the wealthiest, but able to enjoy in life and death the luxury materials of court life.
